mn48:8.13: See [MN 8](https://suttas.hillsidehermitage.org/?q=mn8) and [MN 18](https://suttas.hillsidehermitage.org/?q=mn18). A noble disciple is one who is able to grasp the [“sign” of his mind](https://suttas.hillsidehermitage.org/?q=an6.68), and is thus able to fully disentangle himself from its moods and inclinations *while they are present*, without needing to ameliorate them, and certainly without indulging in them either. That is what “giving up *internally*” means, and it’s the cornerstone of the Middle Way.
mn48:15.2: A noble disciple would know beyond doubt that there is no conceivable occasion, no matter how extreme, where they would lack these seven qualities. They would not only be permanently ingrained, but also effortless.
